title: Definitions
context: [ยง634F-1] Definitions. As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise requires: &ldquo;Governmental body&rdquo; includes a branch, department, agency, instrumentality, official, employee, agent, or other person acting under color of law of the United States, a state, or subdivision of a state or other public authority. &ldquo;Judicial claim&rdquo; or &ldquo;claim&rdquo; includes any lawsuit, cause of action, claim, cross-claim, counterclaim, or other judicial pleading or filing requesting relief. &ldquo;Lacks substantial justification&rdquo; means substantially frivolous, substantially groundless, or substantially vexatious. &ldquo;Motion&rdquo; includes any motion to dismiss, for summary judgment, for judgment on the pleadings or to strike, a demurrer, or any other judicial pleading filed to dispose of a judicial claim. &ldquo;Moving party&rdquo; means any person on whose behalf the motion described in section 634F-2 is filed seeking dismissal of the judicial claim. &ldquo;Person&rdquo; includes any individual, corporation, association, organization, partnership, two or more persons having a joint or common interest, or other legal entity. &ldquo;Public participation&rdquo; means any oral or written testimony submitted or provided to a governmental body during the course of a governmental proceeding. &ldquo;Responding party&rdquo; means any person against whom the motion described in section 634F-2 is filed. &ldquo;SLAPP&rdquo; means a strategic lawsuit against public participation and refers to a lawsuit that lacks substantial justification or is interposed for delay or harassment and that is solely based on the party&rsquo;s public participation before a governmental body. [L 2002, c 187, pt of ยง2] Case Notes Given the allegations in plaintiff&rsquo;s complaint, the filing of the office of disciplinary counsel (ODC) complaint by defendant against plaintiff did not constitute &ldquo;public participation&rdquo; before a governmental body, as defined in this section, because the ODC complaint did not involve &ldquo;oral or written testimony&rdquo; but rather set forth allegations and was a request to the ODC for an investigation. Based on the plain meaning of &ldquo;testimony&rdquo;, even when liberally construed, the ODC complaint and allegations contained therein were not &ldquo;testimony&rdquo; and were not protected under chapter 634F. 129 H. 95 (App.), 294 P.3d 1081 (2013). With respect to plaintiff&rsquo;s claims based on defendant siblings&rsquo; communications with the mayor, the mayor&rsquo;s assistant, and members of the county council, the communications did not constitute &ldquo;testimony&rdquo; submitted or provided &ldquo;during the course of a governmental proceeding&rdquo; and did not constitute a strategic lawsuit against public participation. Even under a liberal construction of this section, nothing in chapter 634F suggests that an individual&rsquo;s unsolicited and informal communication with a government official, when there is no formal process or procedure in progress, constitutes &ldquo;testimony submitted or provided to a governmental body during the course of a governmental proceeding&rdquo;. 129 H. 95 (App.), 294 P.3d 1081 (2013).
